review_title: Worst work environment of all time
pros: Parking isn't too expensive and is available, its a nice campus, near the ocean but these aren't reasons to work somewhere.
cons: Widespread workplace lateral bullying and nepotism that is ignored by all and likely will never change. As someone who has worked in PSE for many years and several institutions across the Province and has comparative experience, RRU is simply the worst PSE I have ever encountered. Embarrassed to also be an RRU alumni now that I have worked there, this University does not practice any of what they teach, very hypocritical that way. Very resistant to progress and change unfortunately, so I did not see a future for myself at RRU as there was no acknowledgement of anything even being wrong therefore no effort to change for the better - very short sighted and sad really - there could be such potential there. As employee you will not be or feel valued, you will experience work place frustration, you will not be engaged, and you may even been bullied and harassed and nothing will be done about it. I would suggest not wasting time working at RRU, I wish I hadn't, it was a waste of 5 years of my career and left me with the worst feelings of professional dissatisfaction. No workplace is perfect but the issues at RRU are so widespread and ignored, there doesn't seem to be even hope for positive change there. I felt a sense of huge disappointment to have spent 5 years working at RRU. I have not one good thing to say about my time there.

pros: The department that I worked within was great to work with, although overworked and under-resourced. The campus is beautiful.
cons:
Underpaid, poor work-life balance due to limited resources and increasing demands. Senior management truly created a sense of bureaucracy and control when making decisions that directly impacted day to day work. Since I have extensive experience in my particular role, I could see that many decisions made from the top down were without a sound understanding or experience in the area that was directly impacted by senior management decisions. Our department was almost never directly communicated to when top-down decisions were made and instead we would find out through media releases / news. 

The pay scales at my level were lower than industry standards. Professional development is not actually supported as much as they let on. Although there is an option to have tuition subsidized as an employee, when I requested this, I learned that the fine print actually says you are eligible for benefit only if budget is available, which it was not. For time off to do my own professional development (paid by myself) I was not properly supported in my PD plan by HR. 

I often had to work several hours of unpaid overtime each week to keep up with demands. Our department requested support and these requests went nowhere with senior management. Staff recognition was extremely poor and staff morale was low. I ended up quitting my job due to unethical situations I was put in due to leadership's incompetence within my department's day to day functions.

review_title: All that glitters is not gold!
pros: Great location, with scenic views.
cons:
As others have mentioned, there is a senior management team in place that runs the university like a little fiefdom.  Highly bureaucratic, patriarchal and condescending. There is the persistent quest to save money, but often at the expense of employee and student satisfaction.  They boast about their unique learning model based on innovative technology, but the technology is antiquated at best. They have a small team of core faculty who rarely teach a full load, and hire a large number of associate faculty who often do not have the required teaching experience.  If this is the university of the future (as is often claimed) it has a long way to go.

This is an organization that had two Cultural Values Assessments in five years, and on both occasions, the assessment indicated that control, bureaucracy and silo mentality were significant issues that warrant concerns about institutional entropy.
